title: Mission Description
content: So, there's more than one Herta... It makes sense now that you think about it. This Herta wants you to head to her office.Looks like Herta developed a Simulated Universe together with a few other members of the Genius Society to explore the truth of the universe.Let's give it a try.

title: Step Description
content: These words resurface in your mind once more. "When you have a chance to make a choice, make one that you know you won't regret."You haven't made up your mind yet, or could it be that you have. However, you're just not sure if anyone else shares your point of view...It's alright. You can hide it deep in your heart and listen to what others think...Is it possible that you all think the same?

text: Find someone to talk to and tell Himeko your decision
Use the Teleport function to fast travel to unlocked locations

html_content:
(Interactive tutorial)
Open Navigation
Use Navigation to quickly move between different locations
Switch to the supply zone.
Select Space Anchors to teleport and get to destinations quickly

speaker: Herta
line: Still haven't made up your mind? Fine. Since I'm interested in you, I'll answer any questions you have.

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Me? Hmm, well, Talking about oneself is as pointless as it gets.

children.text: You're the master of the space station ?

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: On paper, yes. But I don't really care about this place. I built it, put some stuff in, left some people here, and let them just manage themselves.

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Asta's the lead researcher of the space station, so for all intents and purposes, she's the master. I reject the concept of ownership because I don't want the responsibilities that come with it.

children.text: You really are a terrible person.

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: It doesn't matter. Who cares if others don't like me? I know I don't care. As long as I have my own value, I can do whatever I want.

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: While you may have good character, do you have any value? Don't take that the wrong way, I'm genuinely asking you. You might have some value, I just don't know about it.

children.text: What do you actually look like?

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Human, female, young, beautiful, attractive.

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Not much different from what you're seeing now. I modeled it after how I looked, back when I was a kid. It might not be identical, but I'd say maybe 70, 80 percent there?

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Oh, I was so precocious — all I cared about back then was solving the solitary wave problem, ignoring my precious childhood...

children.text: I still have some questions...

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Stellarons, huh? Ask away, I'm listening.

children.text: What exactly is a Stellaron?

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: According to my research, it's a type of lifeform with a special property that tethers it to a certain Path or Aeon 's power.

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Wherever it's located, it responds to that world's desires to advance its civilization. But, this comes at the cost of some form of disaster. The mechanism behind it is likely related to Nanook the Destruction .

children.text: Do you know about the Stellaron Hunters ?

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Oh, that weird bunch. I'm satisfied with just one Stellaron, but they've scoured the universe, obtained several, and still aren't satisfied. I don't know what their true intentions are.

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Screwllum went up against the Stellaron Hunters before. I heard there was a member whose hacking skills were on par with Screwllum.

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Being on the same level as Screwllum — who's probably the best in the universe — is nothing short of spectacular. It's beyond my abilities, computers are not my forte.

children.text: Why am I able to host the Stellaron?

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Ha... That I don't know. Which is why I'm gearing up to solve this mystery.

children.text: I still have some questions...

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: The Express? Shouldn't you be asking Himeko instead?

children.text: What's the Astral Express like?

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: You mean how it looks? Like a train. Well...

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: I was very interested in the Express for a while, and wrote a lot of papers, but forgot where I left them. Now I can't remember anything about it.

children.text: Do you trust the Astral Express?

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Uh-huh.

children.text: What's your relationship with them?

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: We've been business partners for a long time.

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Every once in a while, I'll need them to get me things from other planets, and they often come to me to help them solve problems.

children.text: I still have some questions...

text: About the decision... (When asking for the third time) ▶ Herta: ...You really are weird. What's so good about this place? Even I don't like staying here... ▶ Herta: Ugh. Fine. To be honest with you, I have plenty of ways to seal a mere Stellaron — You just might end up not having a lot of personal freedom. ▶ Herta: If you're so keen to stay... Fine. I'm okay with it. Go speak to Asta. She's the lead researcher. She's in charge. (You now have permission from Herta) Can I stay at the space station? (When asking from the forth time onward) ▶ Herta: As I've said, talk to Asta! She's the lead researcher. She's in charge. Go, go, go. So I should board the Express? ▶ Herta: Well, from an objective standpoint, that's the most rational place for you to be. ▶ Herta: First of all, you have somewhere to live. And you'd be under their protection. Also, it'll be a long trip, so you'll have more opportunities to find a way to save yourself from the Stellaron. Lastly, if the Stellaron really explodes, you won't harm too many people around you. Do I have any other choice? ▶ Herta: Oh, how should I know! It's up to you, you have so many options to choose from. Maybe jump out a hatch, or hop into the Fragmentum and see if any monsters start worshiping you? I still have some questions...

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Uh, what decision? You're gonna have to be more specific.

children.text: (The first dialogue option is variable)
Can I return to the space station?
(When asking for the first time)

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Of course, I'll still be here waiting for you, eh... and the space station will be waiting for you. Returning... it's not impossible.

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: If you wanna be a researcher here, you can just ask Asta. If she's fine with it, I have no complaints.

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: No, hold on — you have a Stellaron within you. I think it's better if you left and came back occasionally. It might be dangerous if you stay for too long...

children.text: Can I stay at the space station?
(When asking for the second time)

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: No. You're way too dangerous. I don't mind personally, but I don't want Asta and others to take the risk.

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: You wouldn't want the Stellaron in you to hurt all the people in the space station either, right?

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Just come back once in a while. You will always be welcome at the space station — just don't stay for too long.

children.speaker: Herta
children.line: Okay, suit yourself.

speaker: Asta
line: ▶ (Trailblazer), thank goodness you're all safe.

speaker: Asta
line: It's a pity that we haven't had the chance to talk much, and now the Express is about to leave. Do you have any questions?

text: Is the damage to the space station serious?

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: Madam Herta gave me a piece of code, which she apparently wrote on the way here. I just tried it out and the defense shield's regenerating three times faster than before.

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: Thanks to her, the Antimatter Legion outside is not much of a threat anymore. The space station's repairs and reconstruction can also begin smoothly, but internally...

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: When the Stellaron was extracted, even for that brief moment, it corroded the space station and formed a new space — what we now call the Fragmentum.

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: The part that was corroded is irreversible, so the space station will always be in a state of quasi-Fragmentum.

children.text: What are the effects of the Fragmentum?

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: All existing Fragmentums are connected, so there will be monsters that will enter the space station through its Fragmentum.

children.text: Will I also be corroded by the Fragmentum?

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: Ahh, I'd like to know the answer to that as well.

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: All existing Fragmentums are connected, so monsters will be able to enter the space station through the Fragmentum here. But it shouldn't allow anything to exit your body, so...

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: I talked with Arlan and there's no easy solution to this problem at the moment. We can only increase the security and patrol frequency to protect the ongoing research.

text: Make sure you don't burn yourself out.

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: After all this is over, I'm putting my vacation time in with Madam Herta. I've got it all planned. I'll hop on an airship and give The Blue a good look.

children.text: You can see it from the space station, you know?

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: Be that as it may, taking it in while on vacation and observing it during work are not the same thing.

children.text: Will Madam Herta let you take a vacation?

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: I guess so? I haven't taken leave once since I joined the space station...

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: And if I have an actual, full vacation, I can take my time to collect observational data and finish writing my paper.

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: Of course, there's already a lot of published research on The Blue, but I want to study it myself. It might sound a lot like work, but it's really just a hobby — there are no deadlines or quotas to meet, and I don't get paid.

text: (The third dialogue option is variable, available only once per interaction)
Can I stay at the space station?

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: I like you, but... you have a Stellaron in your body.

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: If you were just wandering around, or if you agreed to be sealed away in an experiment pod, that would be fine.

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: But if you're going to work in the space station long-term, the Stellaron may have some serious effects on the station's Fragmentum. As the lead researcher, that's a risk I cannot take.

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: I can sense your enthusiasm for the space station, but I'm afraid I have to turn you away.

text: (After getting permission from Herta, one time only)

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: Huh? Madam Herta said that?

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: ▶ In that case... I have nothing against it either. Mind you, if Madam Herta was to do something to you, (Trailblazer)...

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: She's not going to care a lot about what you think.

children.text: (You now have permission from Asta as well)

text: Is there really no way I can help?

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: If you wanted to come back and help, of course, I wouldn't refuse you. Dan Heng helped inventory our rare items, March 7th said that she would help out as much as she can and connected over 50 wires in the electrical room. Everyone from the Express is so obliging...

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: ▶ And I think you're pretty good at "meddling" too, (Trailblazer).

children.speaker: Asta
children.line: Sure, no hurry.

speaker: Dan Heng
line: ▶ Oh, it's you, (Trailblazer)... Do you have something on your mind?

text: You're really good at taking care of others.

children.speaker: Dan Heng
children.line: Oh? What did I do?

children.text: You're always the first one to charge into battle.

children.speaker: Dan Heng
children.line: Is that so? Well, I am the train's guard. I suppose it's just instinct.

children.text: Your judgments are always accurate.

children.speaker: Dan Heng
children.line: It's about being observant at all times and carefully making the best choice for the situation. You can do it too.

children.speaker: Dan Heng
children.line: ▶ I think you're not bad yourself, (Trailblazer).

text: I didn't think you approved of me.

children.speaker: Dan Heng
children.line: If you're referring to what I think about you joining the Astral Express... You're overthinking it.

children.speaker: Dan Heng
children.line: My position is simple: It doesn't matter to me. I suggest you ignore my opinions and make your own choice.

text: You don't seem like someone who likes to travel.

children.speaker: Dan Heng
children.line: Being on the Express isn't exactly the same as "traveling" or "adventuring..." The Astral Express symbolizes "trailblazing" you understand?

children.speaker: Dan Heng
children.line: Trailblazing implies the unknown, be it unknown risks or unknown rewards.

children.speaker: Dan Heng
children.line: In my opinion, the unknown is no more terrifying than the known... In fact, the unknown signifies something we can control and change.

children.text: I'm a little hesitant.

children.speaker: Dan Heng
children.line: Don't use hesitation as an excuse. If you hesitate for too long, your original way of thinking will eventually cease to exist.

children.text: I understand.

children.speaker: Dan Heng
children.line: Mm, okay then.

children.text: Dan Heng gives a slight nod and shifts his gaze elsewhere.

speaker: March 7th
line: ▶ Hey, (Trailblazer)! I heard the news. You're coming with us on the Express, right?

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: Oh come on, you know that's what you want deep down inside. I can see it on your face.

text: Do you want me to come along?

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: Do I even need to say it? I think we're becoming fast friends... isn't that enough?

speaker: March 7th
line: But you look like you've got something on your mind... come on, out with it!

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: Getting nostalgic already?

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: Y'know, when you were passed out, all I thought was I had to look after you. And then you picked up the bat! Just incredible!

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: In the blink of an eye, you knocked that big fella into Mr. Yang's black hole and saved me... I still haven't thanked you properly yet...

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: Nah, we're not splitting up here...

text: How did you join the Express?

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: I'd like to know too, because I was already on the Express when I woke up.

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: I was just drifting out there in space and got picked up by the Express. Amazing, right?

text: Does that kind of thing happen often?

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: Crazy stuff like that? Not too often. It sure freaked me out.

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: But every encounter I've had since coming aboard the Express has been strange to say the least.

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: For example, going to the desert to catch something called a "sandfish," correcting a gravitational field to flip an upside-down castle, or almost getting my head cracked open by a galena ball falling from the sky while trying to avoid a sleeping reindeer on the road—

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: Huh... looking back now, it all seems quite dangerous... But I had the crew there with me, so the problems didn't seem all that bad.

text: I'm thinking about if I should get on the Express...

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: Of course you should! Why wouldn't you?

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: There's only four of us now, plus Pom-Pom. Each of us can have our own carriage to sleep in! You wouldn't have the heart to leave your carriage unmanned, would you?

children.text: That sounds more like a problem for you guys.

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: ▶ Join us, (Trailblazer). Then it wouldn't be a problem anymore.

children.text: I don't know what the carriage is like.

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: Then come aboard and take a look for yourself.

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: ▶ I'll be waiting for you, (Trailblazer).

speaker: Himeko
line: So, have you thought things through?

text: I want to join the Express.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Then come with me.

children.text: (Go to next dialogue)

text: I've made up my mind. I'll stay.

children.text: (This option only appears if you have gotten permission from Herta and Asta)

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Stay? But Herta...

children.text: Herta and Asta both gave me the green light.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Is that so... Well, I respect your choice.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: ▶ Take care, (Trailblazer). We'll come back now and then to see you.

children.text: So long, Himeko.
(Go toAlternative Ending)
I need some more time to think...
I need some more time to think...

text: I still have something to talk to you about, Himeko.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Hm? Go ahead, speak your mind.

children.text: Thank you.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: There's no need to be so formal. You helped us defeat that big fella, anyway. Plus, If we keep speaking pleasantries, we'll waste a whole day.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: You've done me a huge favor by defending the space station from the Antimatter Legion. And know that while Herta may not admit it, she owes me one. And she will not refuse me if I ask for a favor in return...

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: And it's probably not too much to ask for a rare item from the space station, right?

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: How about we continue talking on the Express? I'll make you a cup of coffee, my special blend.

children.text: Have you taken care of everything you need?

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Haha, I was ready ages ago. *sigh* I've been here so many times before, it should've been just an ordinary trip for me.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: But everything's not so ordinary anymore, is it?

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Walking the same path over and over will never be the same, there will always be something new. That's the meaning of trailblazing.

children.text: What's the next stop for the Express?

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: As always, to follow in the footsteps of Akivili .

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Sometimes, we stop on other worlds and we'll continue to do so. There are countless "next stops" in the galaxy.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: I love the vast reaches of space, and the Express does too. I want to seek out new worlds, and the Express wants to return to its former path.

children.text: Why invite me to join?

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Because you're different.

children.text: Because of the Stellaron?

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: While that might be the biggest reason, it's not the only one.

children.text: I'm very self-aware.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Well, the fact that you have a Stellaron in your body is not something most people can boast about.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: I think you need a chance. A chance to discover just how different you really are from everyone else. Everybody keeps telling you about how special you are, and how you have a Stellaron inside you...

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: But that's already plain as day to you. And no matter who tells you — be it me, or Herta, or anybody — it's not the same thing as feeling it yourself.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: You have to experience enough to know if you've gained or lost anything because of the Stellaron, and to know who you really are... Learn to control the Stellaron and then you can control your destiny.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: The Stellaron might still be an enigma, but the fact of the matter is — it's a part of you. And you have to embrace this before you can move forward into the future.

children.text: I don't have any more questions.

text: I need some time to think...

children.speaker: March 7th
children.line: Let's go~

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Time to get on.
Ahem!
I'm over here.

line: Hey, you over there looking dumbfounded. Yes, Pom-Pom's talking to you.
Himeko told Pom-Pom about your situation. Now listen up, Pom-Pom will only say this once.
Pom-Pom's sure there have been lots of people telling you how special you are lately, but this is the Astral Express, and everyone on here has their secrets.
Since you chose to board, you can abide by the rules. You're not the only special one here. You'd best remember that.
I'm Pom-Pom, the conductor. Just come find me if you have any trouble.

title: Step Description
content: You boarded the amazing Astral Express, and it's time to get familiar with its passengers and facilities! From now on, this will be your home.

text: Complete Operation Briefing according to the instruction to obtain rewards

html_content:
(Interactive tutorial)
Open Interastral Peace Guide
Complete Operation Briefing to get the corresponding rewards.
Select Strategic Training
In Strategic Training, you can learn combat-related knowledge and receive corresponding rewards.
(TapTapon mobile/PressPresson controller/ClickClickon keyboard) here to begin basic training

speaker: Welt
line: Oh, it's you. How do you feel?

children.speaker: Welt
children.line: Great. Looks like your stamina is really quite special.

children.speaker: Welt
children.line: ...I'll check you out in a minute.

children.speaker: Welt
children.line: Tasteful... Oh, you mean the train? I was asking how you felt physically.

children.speaker: Welt
children.line: You are right, though. Looking at the interior decoration, you can tell that trailblazers have quite good taste.

speaker: Welt
line: In any case, I have to thank you for saving March.

children.speaker: Welt
children.line: Heh, all I did was calm that thing inside you down temporarily...

children.speaker: Welt
children.line: ...I don't want to frighten you, but the truth is you won't ever be in the clear while it is still inside your body.

text: I couldn't just stand by and watch.

children.speaker: Welt
children.line: It's good that you think so. Someone with that mindset and the actions to back it up — that is the true meaning of the word "hero."

text: I didn't think too much about it...

children.speaker: Welt
children.line: Helping others without a second thought — that is the most important quality of a hero.

speaker: Welt
line: However, as long as the Stellaron is still in your body, you should be careful what you do. I don't know if Himeko and I can suppress it again.

speaker: Welt
line: But I won't bore you any longer. So much happened at the space station, you must be tired.

speaker: Welt
line: There should be some time until the next warp jump, so feel free to walk around and familiarize yourself with the environment.

speaker: Welt
line: But I won't bore you any longer. So much happened at the space station, you must be tired.

speaker: Welt
line: There should be some time until the next warp jump, so feel free to walk around and familiarize yourself with the environment.

speaker: Himeko
line: What do you think? Does the Astral Express look the same as you imagined?

text: As I expected, it looks like a train.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Everyone on the Express is a passenger.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: We're all heading towards an unknown destination, like we are traveling together.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Maybe that's why the Trailblaze chose such a look.

text: I feel like it's missing something...

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: March said something like that at first, too.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Seems like you young people have similar tastes.

speaker: Himeko
line: Oh right — March and Dan Heng should both be in their rooms right now.

speaker: Himeko
line: You can go look for them. You youngsters should get along well.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: Ah, you know, young people! Their rooms always reflect their personality.

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: You can go and... have a look around?

children.speaker: Himeko
children.line: We usually meet up here, but our personal cabins are in the next carriage.

speaker: Himeko
line: Also, don't mind Pom-Pom's antics. They're actually pretty interested in you. It's just that we haven't had new passengers on the Express for a long while.

speaker: Himeko
line: I won't steal Pom-Pom's thunder. If you have any questions, just go ask our conductor.

speaker: Himeko
line: Also, don't mind Pom-Pom's antics. They're actually pretty interested in you. It's just that we haven't had new passengers on the Express for a long while.

speaker: Himeko
line: I won't steal Pom-Pom's thunder. If you have any questions, just go ask our conductor.

speaker: Pom-Pom
line: Here already? I was just engaging in pleasantries. How can I help?

children.speaker: Pom-Pom
children.line: Oh? Why are you interested in her room?

children.speaker: Pom-Pom
children.line: Ah, Pom-Pom remembers Himeko saying that you saved her...

children.speaker: Pom-Pom
children.line: Mmm, very brave! Very foolhardy! But that is what a Trailblazer should be like.

children.speaker: Pom-Pom
children.line: March 7th's room is in the Express Sleeper Compartment. She's always running around, so she might not be there.

children.speaker: Pom-Pom
children.line: Dan Heng's room? Oh, you mean the archives.

children.speaker: Pom-Pom
children.line: He's just... sort of living in there, I guess. I can't be bothered getting him out.

children.speaker: Pom-Pom
children.line: March 7th's room is right next to the Archives. You can visit him on the way.

children.text: (Will result in optional step [(Optional) Investigate the phonograph])

children.speaker: Pom-Pom
children.line: You recognize this as well?

children.speaker: Pom-Pom
children.line: Himeko always likes to bring back weird junk and try to fix it.

children.speaker: Pom-Pom
children.line: That also got modified a bit.

text: That's all my questions for today.

children.text: (Will result in step [Head to the Passenger Cabins])

children.speaker: Pom-Pom
children.line: Pom-Pom still needs to prepare for the Express' warp jump. You can look around the place yourself.

children.speaker: Pom-Pom
children.line: No matter where you go on this train, Pom-Pom will always have my eyes on you.

text: (When attempting to enter the Passenger Cabins before talking to Pom-Pom)

speaker: Pom-Pom
line: Hey! Y—You don't have any questions to ask Pom-Pom!?

speaker: Pom-Pom
line: Is it because you think Pom-Pom talks too much? Or is it Pom-Pom's age? You youngsters gotta learn to bridge that generation gap.

speaker: Pom-Pom
line: Himeko likes using the Phonograph a lot. She says it can play melodies from the past.

speaker: Pom-Pom
line: Welt likes collecting these jet-black discs. It seems like they could be antiques. He'd be very happy if you could bring a few back.

speaker: Pom-Pom
line: You just left. Why are you back again!?

speaker: Pom-Pom
line: Go, go. I'm busy here and I don't have time for you.

speaker: (Trailblazer)
line: ▶ (There seems to be the sound of electronic equipment...)

speaker: Dan Heng
line: Hm? Who's there?

children.speaker: Dan Heng
children.line: ...Oh, it's you. The door's not locked. Come in.

children.speaker: Dan Heng
children.line: I learned to sense incoming visitors after people kept barging in so frequently.

title: Step Description
content: You boarded the amazing Astral Express. From now on, this will be your home. A new adventure is about to start. Prepare to warp jump to a new world!
